item.title: Core Knowledge of Network Communication
item.description:
Core Knowledge of Network Communication

1. Core concepts

1. Socket

What it is: An extension mechanism for inter‑process communication (IPC)
Use: Establish network communication channels (TCP/UDP)
Flow:

  • Server: socket → bind → listen → accept
  • Client: socket → connect → write/read → close
    Note: handle byte‑order conversion (htonl/ntohl)

2. TCP vs UDP

Feature TCP UDP
Connection Connection‑oriented (3‑way handshake) Connectionless
Reliability Reliable (retransmission) Unreliable
Data form Stream socket Datagram socket
Use cases File transfer, web browsing Real‑time video, DNS

2. Server models

1. Iterative server

Limitation: Single‑threaded blocking; cannot handle concurrent requests.

2. Process/Thread model

Process approach:

  • Use waitpid() to avoid zombie processes
  • Parent must reap child resources

Zombie handling details:

  1. Cause:

    • Child terminates but parent never calls wait()
    • Consumes process table resources

  2. Solutions:

    • Synchronous reap: 
      waitpid(pid, NULL, 0);
    • Async reap (recommended): 
      signal(SIGCHLD, [](int) {
 while(waitpid(-1, NULL, WNOHANG) > 0);
});

  3. Special cases:

    • If parent exits first, init adopts and reaps
    • Batch reaping requires a loop

Thread approach:

  • Must synchronize shared variables
  • More complex critical‑section control

3. Process pool optimization

Type Characteristics
Static pool Pre‑created processes, fixed concurrency
Dynamic pool Maintain min/max idle processes

3. High‑performance I/O models

1. Traditional blocking

Characteristics:

  • Single thread blocks on I/O
  • Low resource utilization

2. Select/Poll

Feature Select Poll
Mechanism Bitmap FD scan Linked list FD scan
Max connections 1024 (FD_SETSIZE) No hard limit
Efficiency O(n) scan O(n) scan
Portability All platforms All platforms

3. Epoll

Core mechanism:

  1. Registration via epoll_ctl (red‑black tree)
  2. Ready list maintained by kernel
  3. Trigger modes:
    • LT (level‑triggered)
    • ET (edge‑triggered)

Advantages:

  • O(1) event notification
  • Supports massive connections (C1000K)

4. NIO (Non‑blocking I/O)

Core components:

  1. Channel: full‑duplex pipes (SocketChannel/FileChannel)
  2. Buffer: ByteBuffer/CharBuffer
  3. Selector: multiplexer (based on epoll/kqueue)

Workflow:

start
: Create Selector;
: Register Channel;
repeat
: select() for ready events;
: Handle SelectionKey;
repeat while (events?)
stop

5. AIO (Asynchronous I/O)

Principle:

  • Kernel completes I/O and calls back
  • No user‑thread polling

Typical use cases:

  • Large file async read/write
  • High‑latency network ops

6. Comparison

Model Blocking Threading Trigger Use case
Blocking I/O Blocking 1:1 - Low concurrency
Select Non‑blocking 1:N Polling Cross‑platform medium load
Poll Non‑blocking 1:N Polling <10K connections
Epoll Non‑blocking 1:N Event‑driven Linux high concurrency
NIO Non‑blocking 1:N Readiness High throughput
AIO Async 0:1 Callback Latency‑sensitive

Notes

  1. Kernel support:

    • Windows: IOCP is true async I/O
    • Linux: io_uring (>=5.1) is close to true async

  2. Performance thresholds:

    • C10K: Select/Poll bottleneck
    • C100K: Epoll/NIO required
    • C1000K: Epoll + zero‑copy optimization

  3. Complexity:

    • Blocking < Select < Poll < Epoll < NIO < AIO

4. Practical points

1. Daemons

Key steps:

  1. fork()
  2. setsid()
    Redirect standard I/O to /dev/null

2. UDP server

Traits:

  • No listen()/accept()
  • Use recvfrom()/sendto()

3. Other tips

  • Reuse Address: avoid TIME_WAIT port blocking
  • Thundering herd: multi‑process accept contention, needs kernel lock optimizations Server types:
  • I/O‑bound: LNMP (nginx)
  • CPU‑bound: LAMP (Apache)
  • Coroutines: user‑mode threads with lower context switch cost than kernel threads

5. Learning suggestions

1. Diagnostic tools 

netstat -anp # list network connections

2. Classic books

  • Unix Network Programming
  • Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment
